awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Dissecting photoconversion in fluorescent proteins frame by frame
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the mechanism of irreversible color conversion, as observed in a set of fluorescent proteins derived from jellyfish and reef corals. This group of proteins, termed green-to-red photoconvertible fluorescent proteins (pcFPs), has greatly advanced molecular and cellular imaging techniques in the life sciences.  Notably, the light-induced change in appearance has played a critical role in the development of super-resolution methods to image subcellular events beyond the diffraction limit of visible light. The objective of this project is to unravel the connection between protein motion and the rearrangement of chemical bonds, an interplay that is ultimately responsible for the development of red color. Ultrafast spectroscopic methods and computer modeling will be combined with time-dependent biochemical measurements on pcFPs. The correlation of dynamical and chemical processes will help elucidate novel principles in photobiology and enzymology.  This work will facilitate the training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as the training of post-doctoral researchers.  In addition, this project will serve as a cornerstone for a number of outreach activities.  To enhance evidence-based instructional practices, cutting-edge research on pcFPs will be integrated into formal coursework. 


The overarching goal of this work is to investigate how ultrafast atomic motions in a protein's active site are linked to long-range dynamics and catalytic functionality.  To develop a mechanistic model that connects protein motions to key chemical events, femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy (FSRS) will be combined with photoconversion kinetic measurements and molecular dynamics simulations.  Currently, wavelength-tunable FSRS is the only table-top technique that can track bond vibrations starting with photoexcitation.  Mechanistic hypotheses will be tested by evaluating rate and equilibrium constants of pcFPs engineered to bear modified building blocks.  With this synergistic approach, functional models will be developed that integrate ultrafast atomic motions, local side chain rotations and global chain dynamics on the pathway of color modification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

por.por_cntn:
Prof. Chong Fang at Oregon State University (OSU) has completed research (2018-2023) for this NSF MCB project in dissecting photoconversion in fluorescent proteins (FPs) frame by frame, especially on ultrafast timescales, in collaboration with Prof. Rebekka Wachter at Arizona State University (ASU). Notably, the mechanistic understanding of the fluorescence properties of green-to-red photoconvertible FPs, how they originate and evolve on molecular timescales, how the chromophore interacts with the local environment, and how we can tune them with targeted functions such as redder and brighter emissions remains challenging to obtain. This project effectively tackles this problem by implementing wavelength-tunable femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy (FSRS) at the OSU Chemistry laboratory housed in Linus Pauling Science Center, aided by femtosecond transient absorption (fs-TA) and density functional theory (DFT)-based quantum calculations, revealing the fluorescence modulation mechanisms in an array of photochromic FPs.

On the experimental/technological front, the Fang Lab has developed a versatile tunable FSRS setup in the visible range (ca. 480-720 nm) to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio of transient species in condensed phases (e.g., solution, proteins). The synergistic use of steady-state (absorption and fluorescence) and time-resolved (fs-TA) spectroscopy has proven beneficial in selecting the optimal actinic pump (for photoexcitation) and Raman pump-probe pair (for signal generation). The use of a common stimulated emission (SE) band of these FPs for pre-resonance enhancement is effective, highlighted by a comprehensive article (IJMS 2023) benchmarking various green, orange, and red FPs with ground-state FSRS methodology. On the system/knowledge front, the Fang Lab has revealed fluorescence modulation mechanisms of an engineered single-site mutant of an emission-ratiometric Ca2+ biosensor called GEM-GECO1-P377R (2018), a single-site mutant GFP-S205V (2018), a green-to-red photoconvertible FP termed LEA (2020) with previously unknown photoswitching capabilities (2023), a wild-type yellow fluorescent protein for excitation-ratiometric chloride sensing (2021), a green-red emission and excitation ratiometric Ca2+ biosensor REX-GECO1 (2021 and 2023), a large Stokes shift RFP called mKeima (2023), and a red fluorescent protein with a noncanonical chromophore (2023). On the related photosensitive molecular system front, the Fang Lab has studied a tree-fungi-derived conjugated chromophore called xylindein with excited-state intramolecular proton transfer (2021a,b) and a methylated compound to promote ultrafast triplet state formation (2021c), a series of halogenated GFP chromophores in solution (2021), a cyanobacteriochrome photoreceptor with a larger chromophore cofactor than GFP (2021a,b), a tetrazine-encoded superfolder-GFP for high bioorthogonal fluorogenicity (2022), and nitrophenols/nitrophenolates in solution (2023). Such new knowledge generated throughout the entire project funding period has helped to elucidate the chemistry and biophysics for FPs derived from jellyfish and reef corals, and aided protein engineers and chemical biologists to rationally design new FPs and FP-based biosensors for broad applications in chemical, biomedical, and life sciences. In total, 24 peer-reviewed journal articles (including 5 review articles in JCP 2019, Chem. Eur. J. 2021, JPCB 2021, IJMS 2022, and Chem. Asian J. 2023, plus 1 special issue editorial in Front. Mol. Biosci. 2021) have been published with support of this NSF MCB Award.

Such exposure to science and technology, particularly for postdoctoral scholars (3 supported), graduate students (4 Ph.D.s and 1 M.S. awarded during the funding period), undergraduates (3 supported, 2 became graduate students in Princeton and Cornell), high school Latino students across the State of Oregon, and other members of the public (e.g., via new reports, open campus events, and podcast) will remain an integral part of the Fang Lab. The NSF MCB support has provided substantial opportunities for Fang Group's research, teaching, mentoring, and outreach missions. In particular, Prof. Fang and his Open Campus colleague Jos? founded the annual Juntos Chemistry Overnight Camp (JCOC) in June 2017 which has hosted 22-35 Latino high school students per year across Oregon in 2017, 2018, 2019, 2021, 2022, and 2023 (as part of the inaugural week-long Juntos Academy). The annual two-day camp consists of engaging activities from chemistry labs, presentations on color/spectrum and career/scholarship, research lab tour, chemistry jeopardy, and an overnight stay in a college dorm. Close to 10 graduate students have been trained as camp leaders/chaperones over the years.

Since 2018, the tunable FSRS setup at OSU Chemistry has become a nexus for scientists and engineers domestically and internationally. The Fang Lab has studied various FPs (particularly the photoconvertible LEA) and other novel materials from The Genetic Code Expansion Center, Physics, Electrical Engineering, Wood (and Food) Science and Engineering at OSU, University of Oregon, University of Washington, Stanford University, Princeton University, University of Virginia School of Medicine, ASU, UT Dallas, University of Alberta in Canada, Russian Academy of Sciences, Shizuoka University, and University of Tokyo. This growing list substantiates broader impacts on benefiting a diverse group of collaborators and users (STEM learners/practitioners) as the Fang Lab has captured "molecular movies" on a table-top femtosecond laser setup throughout this funding period and beyond, for an essential quest to link microscopic structural events with macroscopic functions.


Last Modified: 10/04/2023
Modified by: Chong Fang

Images (1 of )
  • Roadmap to red: LEA, an engineered ancestral GFP-like protein, could represent a key step for fluorescent proteins to photoconvert. Spectroscopic methods were used to elucidate an intricate map of light-induced transformations with trapped species, enabling a new dual-illumination strategy.
    Taylor Krueger and Chong Fang
    Copyrighted
    Chong Fang
    LEA_PCPS_scheme
  • Ultrafast spectroscopy revealed FRET in action and inhomogeneous populations with different transition dipole moment alignments between the chromophore and an encoded tetrazine on the protein surface. Rational protein design of two new superfolder GFP mutants achieved the record-high fluorogenicity.
    Longteng Tang and Chong Fang
    Copyrighted
    Chong Fang
    TzGFP_NatSci2022
  • Large Stokes shift red fluorescent proteins power bioimaging advances, and the molecular innerworkings were elucidated by Weimin Liu, Chong Fang, and coworkers in Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. (e202212209). The co-existing cis- and trans-chromophores of mKeima undergo distinct pathways in aqueous buffer.
    Ziyu Wang, Weimin Liu, and Chong Fang
    Copyrighted
    Chong Fang
    mKeima_2023
  • The LEA-A69T mutant significantly diminishes the photoswitching and photoconversion capability versus LEA. Our implementation of complementary spectroscopic techniques from femtosecond transient absorption to stimulated Raman (FSRS) provide crucial information about the �onset" of photoswitching.
    Taylor Krueger and Chong Fang
    Copyrighted
    Chong Fang
    LEA_ProteinSci_TOC
  • Structural fingerprints from FSRS (stimulated Raman) were used to discover a �green� chromophore in a �red� protein, representing a �double-donor� structure to promote charge transfer and red emission of aY-sfGFP. Brighter red fluorescence was achieved by a rationally designed single-mutant protein.
    Cheng Chen and Chong Fang
    Copyrighted
    Chong Fang
    aminoGFP_2023CCCF
  • Red fluorescent proteins (RFPs) have powered bioimaging advances in life sciences due to their long-wavelength emissions and reduced phototoxicity. A critical correlation of the available crystallographic and spectroscopicresults can provide ultrafastand functional structural dynamicsinsights.
    Taylor Krueger, Cheng Chen, and Chong Fang
    Copyrighted
    Chong Fang
    RFP_CAJ2023
